blocks.text: SEVENTEENTH DAY — Sunday, July 1, 1956. From Trail, Oregon to Crater Lake Nat'l Park; north through central Oregon via Bend; pass Mt. Hood; to Columbia River Highway at Hood River; west to Portland (at night); to Forest Grove, Oregon.
With Oregon on Pacific Standard time, Gordon indicates his watch is now four hours behind our regular Eastern Daylight time.

( Opposite Page) The waters of Crater Lake are of so intense a blue color once seen they are never forgotten. Several thousand years ago mighty Mount Mazama, a great volcano, literally "blew its top" with a tremendous discharge of ash and lava to form Crater Lake where the mountaintop once stood.
Gordon's precarious position is well over 1,000 feet above the waters of the lake.

blocks.text: Snow far as the eye can see. We learn fifty feet of snow is about average per season, while the 1932–1933 season produced seventy-three feet. Even on July 1 some of the drifts are twenty feet high.

blocks.text: North through central Oregon headed for Bend we come upon a volcanic area and this strange lava butte (the signs tell the story). We decide to drive a road to the top of the butte; Kitty is driving; it happens to be the most hazardous ride of the whole trip...the road barely wide enough for two cars, no guard rails or mounds for protection....and we are on the out-side going up.

Volcanic Area
Some of the recent volcanic activity in western America caused the spectacular and strange lava formations. Cinder cones, and caves in this vicinity lava butte. A ginger cone contains a crater is feet deep The fault beginning here extends to southeast toward the Paulina mills In distance several huge cave some containing per petal ice formations may be found to the north and east of here.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service

blocks.text: ( Opposite page ) First seen from a distance of more than sixty miles, Oregon's Crowning Glory, Mt. Hood, rises to a height of 11,245 feet. It is the highest point in Oregon.
After circling the eastern slopes of Mt. Hood on a tortuous road we begin the descent to the Columbia River. The snow-capped peak in the far distance is in the State of Washington.
Darkness is fast falling as we proceed on US 30 through the impressive Columbia River Gorge of the Cascade Mountains. We stop briefly to see Bonneville Dam.
Graceful Multnomah Falls tumbles over a 620 foot cliff beside the scenic Columbia River Highway.

blocks.text: EIGHTEENTH DAY — Monday, July 2, 1956. Forrest Grove, Ore. west to Pacific Coast at Seaside; to Astoria; across mouth of Columbia River by ferry to State of Washington; north to Aberdeen; east to Olympia and Tacoma; bypass Seattle; east to North Bend, Wash.
Grim evidence of what a forest fire can do to a once beautiful forest.

After leaving Forest Grove we make a mistake,
for instead of heading due west we should have headed southwest to drive along the spectacular cliffs of the Oregon coast over-looking the Pacific Ocean. It was our opinion these cliffs extended further north. By head-
ing due west we reach Seaside, one of the State's chief resort centers but lacking in any special appeal.

From Seaside, north along the coast to Astoria at the mouth of the Columbia River, a city founded in 1811 by partners of John Jacob Astor in the fur trade. A circular frieze on the Astor Column (left) portrays the history of the first settlers in the Oregon Country. Cindy and Louise make the climb to the top.

blocks.text: We cross the Columbia River by ferry from Astoria to the State of Washington. The distance is about five miles, and the ferry toll is between $5 - $6.
The day is chilly and damp. The Washington shore is shrouded in mist. Some of the children are getting very short on clothing.

blocks.text: STATE LAW PROHIBITS DISCHARGING FIRE WORKS WITHIN 250 OF STAND.
First thing in the State of Washington is a stop to buy fire crackers (of all things).
North in Washington to Aberdeen, a lumbering center. Here, for the first time on the trip, we make a definite turn eastward...and home.
The Capitol of Washington at Olympia, a city founded in mid-19th century.

Trouble! Between Olympia and Tacoma, near the entrance to Ft. Lewis, Gordon's car is struct from the rear by another car whose driver was "looking for a gas station". The photograph shows extensive damage to the rear of Gordon's car, which prevented the trunk being fully closed all the rest of the way home; in addition, the force of the blow broke the front seat loose from its track making driving extremely uncomfort- able. Fortunately, no one was hurt. Damage amounting to $149 was fully paid after reaching home by the other party's insurance company.

With weather bad and the car damaged, we decide to bye-pass Seattle and skip the Mt. Rainier area entirely. Here (left) we stop for the night at North Bend just as we are about to re-enter the Cascades. Note the low hanging rain clouds.

blocks.text: NINETEENTH DAY — Tuesday, July 3, 1956. North Bend, Wash. east across the state via Wenatchee to Grand Coulee Dam; to Spokane; northeast into Idaho as far as Priest River. 9:30 A. M. to 8:00 P. M. 375 miles — total 6,210 miles.
(Left) With clear weather again, we begin the climb across the Cascades from R#10 to R#15 and the Wenatchee Valley on a road with 525 turns in 17 miles. (Try it...it's really hard work.)
The Wenatchee Valley of Washington is known all over the country for the quality of its fruit. The Valley is scenically beautiful, with mountains on all sides.
We buy peaches and cherries...and are surprised at the prices right at the orchards. Apparently the growers have banded together in co-operatives to maintain high prices.
At the city of Wenatchee we again encounter the Columbia River, follow it for 16 miles, then rise to a high plateau of wheat lands as we head eastward through central Washington.

blocks.text: Here is the Grand Coulee, formerly the bed of the Columbia River which eons ago was diverted from its course by glacier blockade; now a tremendous reservoir into which water is pumped from Lake Roosevelt (formed by the Grand Coulee Dam) in flood season, later to be gradually distributed to irrigate more than one million acres of land. The cliffs alongside this huge trough rise as high as 1,200 feet.

The cliffs alongside this huge trough rise as high as 1,200 feet.

blocks.text: (Left) Grand Coulee Dam, said to be the greatest man-made structure in the world, is the greatest single producer of electric power. The Dam is 4,300 feet long, 500 feet thick at the base, and rises 550 feet (high as the Washington Monument) above the bed of the Columbia River. In addition to the production of electric power, the Dam helps in flood control and in irrigation. The waters behind the Dam form Lake Roosevelt, which extends 151 miles into Canada.

After viewing Grand Coulee Dam, we run through light showers to Davenport, Washington, where we have supper and receive mail from home. Kitty waives the mail, so the children will know they have not been forgotten, as she emerges from the post office. Getting mail from home at pre-arranged locations is of particular importance to the children on the trip.
We enter Idaho's entreme northern northernthe rrrr nneck at the Pend Oreille River... and drive only about six miles to Priest River where we locate a motel for the night.
Cindy applies cold cream to Kathy's face as she prepares for bed at Priest River motel.

blocks.text: TWENTIETH DAY — Wednesday, July 4, 1956. Priest River, Idaho to Montana line; to Kalispell; visit Hungry Horse Dam; across Rocky Mountains at Glacier National Park (Going-to-the-Sun Hwy.); enter Great Plains; to Shelby, Montana.
Moxie River Dam in northern Idaho. We are within 25 miles of the Canada border.
The blacksmith can still make a living in Idaho, as this shop attests.

PARK UNITED STATES

Glacier National Park in the Rocky Mountains of northwestern Montana was set aside as a national park in 1910. It comprises an area of 1,583 sq. miles...is outstandingly beautiful glacier-carved country which gives the Park its name. The fifty mile Going-to-the-Sun Highway across the mountains of the Park is a marvel of road engineering; its scenic attractions compare favorably with any in the United States.

High Point of the Glacier Park trip is Logan Pass (6,664') on the Continental Divide.
This is Wednesday, July 4; we have been traveling on the western side of the Divide since Saturday, June 23.
The mountains of Glacier Park, like the Great Tetons, have a character all their own - once seen, they are easily recognized and never forgotten.

blocks.text: As we leave the park we enter the Blackfeet Indian Reservation which has the usual curio shop for tourists. A member of the tribe examines with concealed amusement a war bonnet which is supposed to be a copy of the one worn by his forefathers.
Gordon is anxious to be on the way...but it requires at least an hour to convince the other members of his party the fascination of the urio shop is an expensive fascination indeed.

blocks.text: As always when leaving the Rocky Mountains to the east, one is surprised at the suddenness with which one enters the Great Plains. One minute there appear to be mountains on every side...the next flat, treeless plains stretch far as the eye can see. Actually, it is not quite this sudden, but almost everyone is conscious of the dramatic change from lofty mountains to unobstructed plains.
Supper at a remote town with the odd name of Cut Bank.

blocks.text: TWENTY FIRST DAY - Thursday, July 5, 1956. Shelby, Montana to Havre, to Wolf Point, to Circle, to Wibaux, for night. 9:15 A. M. to 7:45 P. M. 467 miles – total 7,082 miles.

The town fathers of Montana would profit by a visit to the beautiful and tidy villages of New England. Granting Montana is closer to pioneer days, nevertheless, there is little of beauty here: the buildings have no symmetry, there is little grass and practically no trees, most of the streets are still unpaved to the extent we were unable to secure breakfast in Shelby because the main street was a mass of mud. We did manage to alight in Chester (right), but here too most of the streets are virtually quagmires.

The Great Plains in this northern part of the country are not so flat as in Kansas; rather, there are long, great swells of land like the waves of mid-ocean. We have never been able to learn why there are so few trees. Towns stand out from a great distance since the view is unobstructed.
A sharp turn south at Wolf Point takes us across the Missouri River. We hear R#2 is almost impassable in N. D. due to repairs.
More of the history of Montana. The Indians are given unusually sympathetic treatment.

blocks.text: X CUSTER TRAIL X THE YELLOWSTONE EXPEDITION OF NEW MEXICO ORGANIZED TO DRILL THE HOSTILE AREA, MARKED FROM FORT BROWNING TO GALLUP. MAY 18TH AND CAMPED A SHORT DISTANCE TO THE SOUTHWEST OF THIS MARKER ON THAT DAY IN 1936 ABOUT A MILE WEST OF NEW SALON THE TRAIL OF CUSTER'S CAVALRY INTERSECTS THIS HIGHWAY CONTINUES A GENERAL WESTERLY DIRECTOR, AND ENTERS PIERRE NEAR BLACK HILL. NORTH DAKOTA EXTENDS TO THE BANKS OF THE MISSOURI RIVER IN SOUTHERN MONTANA WHERE CUSTER AND A PORTION OF HIS CAVALRY WERE KILLED ANIMATED BY HOSTILE HORSES ON JUNE 25, 1936
Along this way in 1876 came Custer and his calvarymen headed for Montana and his fateful meeting with the Sioux.
A scene in sparsely populated North Dakota. There is much loneliness here. That heavy storm chased us across the whole state.

The Capitol of North Dakota in Bismarck looks like a modern office building. Just as we approached the Capitol steps we found the governor was being made a member of some sort of fraternal order. The governor stands in the center in the dark suit. We never did learn his name.
WELCOME TO MINNESOTA

Across the Red River at Fargo, North Dakota,
to enter Minnesota at Moorhead.

blocks.text: TWENTY THIRD DAY — Saturday, July 7, 1956. Wadena, Minn. via Brainerd to Duluth; across northern Wisconsin; into Michigan's northern peninsula as far as Iron Mountain. 7:15 A. M. to 6:30 P. M. 431 miles — total 8,015 miles.
In central Minnesota we cross the Mississippi River, at this point about as wide as our Conestoga Creek. The rain caught up with us during the night and remained with us for one and a half days.

The water is choppy in Lake Supe-rior as we round the point from Duluth, which is situated on bluffs above the Lake. We are now in Wisconsin at the edge of the city of Superior. The harbor and docks in this vicinity rank second only to New York in yearly tonnage, chiefly ore, coal and grain.
A quick lunch somewhere in this sparsely settled part of northern Wisconsin. Rain is falling heavily outside.
This long wooden structure at Ashlandland, Wis. permits ore cars to run out over Lake Supe prior to deposit their loads in waiting boats.

blocks.text: Across the wilderness country of Michigan's northern peninsula. It is almost all wood-land, ideal for hunting and fishing.
An early stop at Iron Mountain, Mich. Not knowing what accommodations are available beforehand, we decide to play it safe. ($10.)

TWENTY FOURTH DAY — Sunday, July 8, 1956. Iron Mountain, Mich. to Escanaba, to St. Ignace; by ferry across Straits of Mackinac to Mackinaw City; to Petoskey, to Traverse City, to Shelby, Mich., for night at Ben Near's home.

From Iron Mountain to St. Ignace, thru the wilderness country, we drive under a constant downpour of rain. There are occasional views of Lake Michigan. We are all surprised at the heavy traffic in this remote region.

By ferry across the Straits of Mackinac from St. Ignace to Mackinaw City. A bottleneck of traffic at the northern terminal delays us for two hours.
(Right) One of the great bridges of the world is being erected across the Straits (barely discernible through the mists) at a cost of approximately $100 million.

blocks.text: As we proceed, making excellent time, it becomes apparent we are this day within striking distance of home. We tell the children we will stop when ever they become tired, but they are now more interested in getting home than continuing the trip for another day. They urge us to keep going.
Back in Pennsylvania again (a welcome sight) as we leave the Ohio Turnpike to enter its Pennsylvania counterpart. A final meal on the Turnpike.
Total trip - 9,217 miles.

blocks.text: Another night spent at a motel near Bristol, on the Virginia-Tennessee line. The next morning, at Bluefield, Herman leaves for Huntington while Gordon heads eastward for Richmond.
The Elks National Memorial Home at Bedford,
En route to Huntington, Hawks Nest State Park near Charleston, W. Va.

After the convention of the W. Va. Education Ass'n in Huntington, Gordon in mid-afternoon follows the Ohio River to Wheeling, spends the night in a motel close to the Penna. line, and drives to Lancaster on the Penna. Turnpike the following day.
A bad accident on the Penna. Turnpike. One woman from Canada lies dead in the overturned car, while four others are seriously injured.

End - trip to Knoxville,
Richmond and Huntington.
By the end of the year 1956, the Chrysler, purchased in April, 1955 has about 52,000 miles recorded on the speedometer.
